replies.commentBody: I’m guessing that you aren’t old enough to remember Watergate. It was only by getting the traces of dirt out into the light that the courts got involved. When they did, the press got some leverage. And then Congress joined in, and eventually the entire edifice that was the Nixon administration fell. But only because the word got out to us long before the full outlines of the catastrophe were even imagined.

That is a fair characterization of what has been published so far.

However, we should keep in mind the following facts, which are extremely suspicious and would be fantastically improbable unless collusion were taking place.

The Trump Administration:

1. Had multiple contacts with multiple high-level Russian government officials, through a variety of pre-planned meetings and other channels, and involving multiple Trump campaign members

2. Denied such contacts repeatedly, through statements by Donald Trump and by others, including under oath

3. Altered the language of the RNC party platform document to eliminate explicit support for the government of the Ukraine with weapons

4. Did so on the basis of a request by Donald Trump himself, in March of 2016, according to JD Gordon, his NSA adviser at the time

5. Began a public relations campaign with the explicit purpose of trying to sway public opinion away from the hostility that the Putin regime has engendered with its invasions of neighbors, failures to uphold democracy and the rule of law, and criminal activities including the murders of political opponents, and towards a possible detente that is wholly undeserved

6. Attempted as private citizens to undermine the policies of a sitting President with an adversarial foreign power without authorization, a violation of the Logan Act

So, while the evidence is circumstantial at the moment, it's certainly worth the scrutiny it is currently being subjected to, and a lot more.
HEAR, HEAR.  Especially to those calling for General Sessions' resignation.

comments.commentBody: There are a fair number of articles appearing in the NYT these days positing that someone or some group "may" have done something, on the basis of circumstantial evidence. I am the opposite of a Trump fan but this type of journalism seems to be fomenting the current climate of divisiveness and hastening a rush to judgement based on what one would like to be true rather than what might actually be true - in this case, that Trump staffers were in fact complicit with the Russians. What is written in this article gives excellent cause for journalists to follow up on the situation but it seems to me that an article isn't called for until definitive evidence has been uncovered one way or the other - or, the sheer volume of circumstantial evidence is such that drawing any other conclusion seems ridiculous. Based on this article, it does not seem that that point has been reached as yet.

If the republican's don't get over their own gross self-interest and cut ties with this president* they will not be able to just wash or waive away his stink in 2 years. They think they control his crazy train to their own ends but he'll just end up taking the republican party---and the US---right over the cliff with him.

I expect at least as thorough an investigation of Tr*mp's and his associates' Russian/Kremlin dealings as Sec. Clinton was on the receiving end of regarding her email server. Anything less and the republican party is guilty by association.
Praise be.  They WILL expose the Treasonous Trump.  Now just a matter of time.  Thank god for the prior Admin's foresight.

Thank You! No wonder Trump and his fellow traitors want to silence the NY Times.Please remain vigilant as our democracy needs an open and free press.

An abundance of thanks, also, to Obama and staff, in their quest to help save our democracy, for having the foresight and wisdom to protect such damning and critical information regarding Traitor Trump.

"The concerns about the contacts were cemented by a series of phone calls between Sergey I. Kislyak, Russia’s ambassador to the United States, and Michael T. Flynn,"......If this does not cause President Trump to stand back and allow a thorough independent investigation of the Russian connection, there can be only one logical explanation.
Something's been wrong in Denmark for awhile. But now, it all stinks; and I feel sullied.
The entire Trump administration is going to be the subject of the next Dan Brown novel!

replies.commentBody: Obama knew that Trump would undo it, surely.
i want to know if it was an issue of not enough time to fully investigate... other than a silver bullet post the election would have been construed as just sour grapes ?
who would have believed him

comments.commentBody: I am disappointed the Obama Administration didn't investigate the Russian/Trump election interference much more aggressively before the election. It was clear something really major was going on with the wikileaks only on Hillary Clinton and the Russian people in the Trump campaign.
Thanks Obama!

replies.commentBody:
We must demand nothing less than an INDEPENDENT commission. Much like the 9/11 commission. No special prosecuter, no House investigation. An independent, bipartisan commission. The members should consisit of no one currently holding office. The truth will never be told if left in the hands of the Republicans in the House and Senate. The truth will never surface if we have a new Ken Starr beholden to McConnell and Ryan.

Russia's ties to Trump's Presidency is modern warfare. Treat it like the attack on our soil that it was. Just like 9/11. Settle for nothing less than an independent commission.

comments.commentBody: Looks like a bad moon rising for Trump.  Congress needs to step up and appoint a special prosecutor/investigator and get to the bottom of this mess.  Should not be a partisan issue when the United States is attacked by a foreign government.  Country before party, period.

replies.commentBody:
"There is too much going on, with more stuff coming out every day, for aspects of this not to be true. The very fact the GOP has already twice blocked efforts to continue this investigation sure reeks of something."
The above quote was EXACTLY what was being said about the Clinton's for two decades. Suddenly it is important that something "is going on" and must be fully investigated. Odd how what was not good for the goose is now very good for the gander. And all in his first month as a political figure.

The corrupt world of politics is NOT something that individuals should ever enter without decades of training and experience. Private citizens like Trump or anyone else should take this lesson to heart. No outsiders allowed EVER.

The individuals who are career bureaucrats and politicians guard their world fiercely and will destroy ANY interlopers quickly utilizing every resource up to and including assassination. JFK and MLK investigations were both conducted by the very institutions that might have had a hand in their deaths.

Trump has entered a very dark world where hundreds of billions of dollars are flowing. Who they flow to and how these dollars are allocated is NOT for an individual with the American people's interest at heart to say.
Trump did NOT commit himself to the donors and usual Washington elites and moneyed interests so he will not be "protected" nor will he last out his first term if they have their way. Media is the enabler individuals.

"There is too much going on, with more stuff coming out every day, for aspects of this not to be true."

So it's true. If you throw enough mud, some of it will stick.
Turns out those two contacts with the Russian ambassador were in his capacity as a Senator, he also met with a number of other countries ambassadors for the same reason.

comments.commentBody:
There is too much going on, with more stuff coming out every day, for aspects of this not to be true. The very fact the GOP has already twice blocked efforts to continue this investigation sure reeks of something.

I hope they get to keep at this. Breaking news from WAPO now says Sessions had two separate contacts with the Russian ambassador in the past year.

Now why would that be? Just tell me please, and please know I wasn't born yesterday.

replies.commentBody: Trump in bed with the Russians.  Bad visuals.  Gross.  Seriously.

I have no doubt the Times is digging.
However, i would not trust Trump's tax returns to be accurate or complete.
It will take time, but the Times, Washington Post, New Yorker, Pro Public and others are surely working on this. This is a huge story.
I just hope no reporters or intelligence agencies are murdered as other Putin "enemies" have been.

comments.commentBody: Rachel Maddow explained the Russian connection very clearly, as well as the role of the Bank of Cyprus (Wilbur Ross....hmmm). I think you (NYT) should dig deeper and all of us should be a little more patient. I strongly believe, and I have said this many times before, that if we see trump's tax returns, a lot will become clearer. Russian and trump (and I surmise most of his cabinet) are all in bed together, having a good laugh on us. Keep on digging NYT...Please, keep on digging.
Heroic of them! They put our country first. If only the GOP would do the same.
Hopefully, one day a brave soul at the IRS leaks his tax returns.
If the Trump team has nothing to fear than let the investigation take place, period.  That should be a bipartisan, unifying quest, period.

replies.commentBody:
Yesterday (3/2), JD Gordon went on record as stating that while he was the Trump Campaigns National Security Adviser, Donald Trump requested in March of 2016 that advisers prepare to ensure that the language of the party platform be changed at the RNC. He *specified the language to be used*.

The language would not be finalized until the Republican National Convention in the fall. At that session, Trump advisers persuaded the rest of the committee to soften language supporting the Ukraine by removing any reference to supplying weapons to the Ukrainian government.

Mr Trump is notoriously ignorant of foreign policy, geography, international relations and the responsibilities that the American government has held for 70 years regarding world leadership.

That he would make such a specific request, months in advance, on such an arcane point, entirely on his own *beggars belief*.

At the moment, this is circumstantial evidence, but it is *highly suspicious*, particularly when considered in light of Mr Trump's and his associates' repeated denials of any Russian contacts, evidence proving exactly the contrary, and recent admissions that the denials were false.

The Administration has characterized these denials as taken out of context, the results of poor memory, misunderstandings, or as a result of mishearing the question. They have even asserted that the question asked was different from the language the interviewer claims was used. Videotaped evidence refutes these claims.
Very cogent analysis - my compliments.

I'm not sure you read the same article. Sessions was an early Trump supporter and a key adviser during his campaign. He has also now admitted to meeting with the Russian ambassador twice during the election. It would be ignorant to believe that a top campaign adviser was not talking to his candidate about these kinds of meetings. It is wrong to use a wait and see policy when a serious national security threat may now be in the White House.

comments.commentBody:
On first reading, I was ready to join the general disapproval voiced by so many commenters. After rereading the article, however, I see multiple references to contacts by "associates" of Mr. Trump. Only associates. Not Mr. Trump himself, nor campaign strategists or planners. Nor do see any claim that Trump or his campaign staff was aware of those contacts. Indeed, those making the contacts might have been creating a scenario in hopes of ingratiating themselves with Trump, for future favors if he were elected.

I am not a Trump fan; he is a complete jerk. But I will await those details before jumping on the Impeach Trump bandwagon.

Trump is a used car salesman. His presidential address was the big shiny hard sell but under the hood are policies that wreak of white nationalism and violence against racial, religious, sexual minorities, disabled bodies, the poor, middle class and the environment.

His actions will show how much of a charlatan he is.

replies.commentBody: It's not just a "Story", it's FACTS.
Hey Sven the motto is: "More Obsession and Less Oppression!".  Thank you NYT and MSNBC for your unfailing dedication to telling the story.

comments.commentBody: The New York Times is obsessed with this non-story.

replies.commentBody: Or a way to pressure and goad Congress into doing the right thing? Whoever leaked to NYT that the intel is protected and disseminated wants Congress and the Administration to know that. It seems laudable to me as a way to insist a proper, thorough investigation happen.
When you have pictures of Trump Staff members having dinner with Putin and being given awards by Putin. It is safe to say we are way beyond "conspiracy".

"Will add fuel to the Obama conspiracy theory."

What Obama conspiracy theory? Birtherism? Are you still demanding to see his long-form birth certificate?

comments.commentBody: Not much new information here, except for the part where the Obama administration preserved information in fear that it would be destroyed or hidden (made super-top-secret).  Will add fuel to the Obama conspiracy theory.

This article is filled with a lot of speculation and insinuation, which has been the case pretty much right along the way in this matter.  Name some names, date some meetings and identify some locations.  Come on, NYT, we are all waiting with bated breath.

replies.commentBody: Trump's budget slashes spending for the big government labs in The Department of Energy working on supercomputers and advanced computing.  Both Russia and China must be thrilled.  Cheap way to sabotage America's technological advantages.

comments.commentBody: I feel like I'm stating the obvious but Russia has found a way to realistically invade countries while spending virtually nothing. The battlefield is the Internet and they are way, way ahead of us. If we allow them to topple our government by having their own puppet they opportunistically put into place then we are well on our way to the New World Order. Better brush up on your Russian 'cause we will all be speaking it if they win. I wonder what they will rename us?

"Fake news"? "Enemy of the people"? I'm not the only one who thinks Trump's attacks on the media are all related to the investigation into Russian hacking, am I? From where I sit, they look an awful lot like an attempt to discount the stories that might lead people to question the legitimacy of his presidency. Kind of like the way that defense attorneys try to discredit the character of witnesses for the prosecution. Or certain politicians try to impugn the character of the more than one dozen women who have accused him of sexual assault.

This is a massive scandal.  Democrats need to learn how to play hardball.  Relentless attacks by the GOP against Democrats during the Clinton and Obama administrations have taken a toll, hence we have president Trump.  Democrats need to pull out all the stops on this. They have got to learn to get tough.  Republican's like Trey Gowdy are brutal and you cannot play badminton while they are playing rugby.

Mr. Obama will be, in many ways blamed for the disastrous election of Donald Trump, and for what most certainly will be even more disastrous effects yet to come of Mr. Trump's tenure.

Mr. Obama did not disclose the information on the meddling publicly, he acquiesced to McConnell's hostage-taking noises about the GOP accusing *him* of manipulating the election if he uncovered the Russian interventions, his prosecution of banks and Wall Street was timid, his infrastructure package too small, his not campaigning 24x7 allowed the narrative to be hijacked by the Tea Party, his not playing Democrats against Republicans, shell-shocked Democrats in need of a vocal fighter.

Alas, it is incontrovertible that Obama always had good reasons for his carefulness, actually was committed to a measured Presidency (in spite of false criticism of an "Imperial" Obama), and always erred in the side of caution.

I suspect in history what will be written is that Obama knew how tottering and hollow was America, and that he proceeded with care to save the country if just a bit longer --if anything, this shows that even a great leader cannot arrest the decline and self-destruction of a nation.

If the White House denies these allegations, then you can be pretty sure they are factual.

Claims from Trump supporters that Obama is behind this don't make any more sense than 8 years of Trump accusing President Obama of not being a US citizen.

If Obama were really out to get Mr. Trump, he would have appointed Merrick Garland to the supreme court by executive action.

Trump has been exposed and he cannot lie his way out of this one. The facts will come out.
